description: Include manufactured items bought in the market or self-made items with a substantial market/trade value(e.g., canoes). List 5 livelihood items (e.g. hoe, machete, fishing net), 5 household items (e.g. cookware, clock, phone), and as many livestock species as necessary (e.g.animals as a food source such as cow and goat, transport animals such as horse and camel, and animals as a farming tool such as ox and elephant). Give the average price of the items in local currency.
The first 10 wealth items will be considered in the surverys. You can change the order, by clicking the move up, move down buttons.

description: In case an extreme event would affect the whole community, who do you think would come forward to deal with this situation?
1 - 5: (1) everyone would deal with the problem individually (5) the entire village would act together
components.name: Group cohesion

description: In case a person/household in the village face an emergency situation, how would the people in the village react? (e.g. big crop loss, illness)
1 - 5: (1) nobody would do anything (5) anyone from the village would help them
components.name: Group solidarity

description: Who looks after the common land and common spaces in the village?
1 - 5: (1) no one does anything (5) the entire village discuss and decide what is to be done
components.name: Group care

description: In this village people trust each other?
1 - 5: (1) people only trust their family or kin  (5) everybody trust everybody
components.name: Group trust

description: Compared to 15 years ago, do you think that people are now more or less engaged in social/collective activities?
components.name: Group change

description: Note: The 1-5 scale do not need to be directly presented to the interviewee, but instead be used as guideline to code the answers that can be purely qualitative / textual. We have not assigned a description to each category (1-5) because we understand that the scale is context-specific.
aspects.label: General
aspects.name: Groups

components.description: How many formal groups doing any of the following activities are there in the village?
components.name: Formal groups numbers

description: On average, how many times do these formal groups meet?
1 - 5: (1) not often (5) very often
components.name: Group meeting frequency

description: On average, how would you assess the level of participation of the villager in these groups?
1 - 5: (1) almost nobody in the village participates (5) almost everybody in the village participates.
components.name: Group participation

description: Note: We understand as "formal groups" when people follow a formal relationship, rules, and policies are established for compliance, and there exists a system of authority.
aspects.name: Formal groups

aspects.description: List of all surveys. Not implemented at the moment
aspects.name: Surveys

description: How many cultivation plots does your household have/ had this year?
only if agriculture was listed as a livelihood activity above!. Include all temporary and permanent plots. Convert local measurement units to hectares, provide an approximate measure
aspects.name: plot sizes

description: What kind of livestock does your household own and how many of those?

Include transport and plowing animals. In general do not include small livestock for home consumption (eg., chicken, ducks, pigs), except in cases where raising these animals is a major livelihood activity of the household and if the numbers are high. Include all temporary and permanent plots. Convert local measurement units to hectares, provide an approximate measure
aspects.name: livestock types and quantities

description: Compared to other people here in the village, how much do you know about the following 3 main activities?

Assess the self-evaluated level of knowledge of the person on the three main livelihood activities practiced in the site. Ask only about the three main activities practiced in the site (from SSI), which may not be the same as those practiced by the respondent. Do not present the list of possible answers to the respondent; instead, coding should be done through interpretation of qualitative answers, combined with direct observation (e.g., if the researcher already knows that the person is recognized as an expert in a given activity).
